abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Program (PRSC-3) is the last in a programmatic series
            of annual poverty reduction support credits to the country.
            PRSC-1 (US$20 million equivalent) was approved in March 2010
            and PRSC-2 (US$30 million equivalent) in February 2011. The
            PRSC credits provide support to a policy and institutional
            reform program emanating from government's development
            strategy articulated in the Fifth National Development Plan
            (FNDP) for the period 2006-2010 and other strategic
            documents and reform programs prepared by the government.
            The successor to the FNDP, the Sixth National Development
            Plan (SNDP) for the period 2011-2015, was prepared by the
            outgoing government and adopted in February 2011. The PRSC
            program is in good alignment with SNDP as well. Policy
            preferences of the new Patriotic Front (PF) government that
            assumed office in September 2011 display commitment to the
            reform activities monitored by the PRSC series. This was
            evidenced in the team's policy discussions with the
            government and progress being made on the activities. The
            Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) identified budget support
            as the primary instrument towards implementing Bank's
            macroeconomic program over the period 2008-11. It provided a
            resource envelope of 15-20 percent of the International
            Development Association (IDA) country allocation for budget
            support. The objectives of the Bank's macroeconomic
            program identified in the CAS are to help Zambia in better
            management of its financial resources, in improving
            accountability and transparency in the use of financial
            resources, and in implementing its reform programs to
            improve public sector efficiency and business environment.
            The PRSC process also provides a forum for broader policy
            dialogue with the government and other major stakeholders.
